Call for speakers

OUR CALL FOR SPEAKERS IS NOW CLOSED.

Thank you for all your submissions, we hope to get back to everyone within 2-3 weeks.

The deadline for submissions was Monday 15th February 2016.

Object-Orientated Views

I’ve seen this too many times in views (grails, ruby-on-rails, velocity)
#if ($user.hasPicture())
#parse (“userPicture”)
#else
## do nothing
#endif

or even worse:
#if ( $user != null)
#show user information
#endif
I mean, didn’t we just study Object Orientation to use polymorphism just for that sort of thing.

What if.

What if we’d get a proper User representation from the domain. Whether it is a user with or without a picture, or if it is a NullObject (UserThatDoesNotExistInSystem), the details don’t need to pollute the views.

In this talk, I will show one possible solution for case like that – getting a User representation from the domain and displaying relevant information in web views. The information rendered in UI differs based on whether user exists or not, it’s data and whether the user is being edited or is only to be viewed.

The patterns used in the code include (but are not limited to)

  • Exhibit pattern (Avdi Grimm, Object on Rails)
  • Command-Query Responsibility Segregation
The best part is. This is live production code written and maintained. By spring 2015 I believe I have gotten some insights about the work, which I am happy to share with.

The talk is about showing real production code using the pattern, and using controllers & views with very few if-statements.

Aki Salmi , Ambientia

Aki has mixed work roles. Being software craftsman, he loves learning new and cool programming languages and paradigms, let it be on front-end, backend, devops, or anything.

On the other hand, Aki is very down-to-earth human being. One of his profession is to be hiking guide. Leading people in circumstances where earning trust really makes a difference.

And, he has learned a new profession, where he aims to bring joy and meaning to work teams' lives. Where the work teams are teachers, nurses, or such.

All this is because Aki is great listener and excellent in building trusting and safe environments

Software Craftsmanship vs Lean Product

You want to get your product out to users, but you want to write clean code. Test your market fast but keep the product maintainable. Lean product development and software craftsmanship just can’t work together, right?

In the red corner, we have Elizabeth Ayer, Product Manager at Redgate. She loves Minimum Viable Products, cunning experiments, and The Lean Startup is her bible. Craftsmanship to her means wasting time polishing internals. Everyone loves sausages regardless of what goes on inside the factory.

In the blue corner, we have Alastair Smith, Founder of the Cambridge Software Craftsmanship Community. He loves clean code, test-driven development, and The Pragmatic Programmer is his bible. Lean product development to him means half-finished products, mountains of technical debt. It’s less “fail cheap, fail often”, than just simply “#fail”.

Does Craftsmanship take focus off the end user? Does Lean make poor trade-offs between speed and quality? Can the same team follow both principles? Alastair and Elizabeth will explore common misconceptions, as well as genuine areas of contention between the two approaches. Come see if they can ever join forces to create products users love.

Alastair Smith , Redgate Software Ltd

Alastair is part of the team at Redgate building ingeniously simple tools. He enjoys writing C# on the back end and HTML/CSS/JavaScript on the front end, but he's tried a number of languages and found his real interests lie in good coding practices and ensuring software quality with automated tests. He has a passion for rooting out and destroying legacy code, and for promoting good practice in teams.

He is the founder of the Cambridge Software Craftsmanship Community and a co-organiser of DDD East Anglia.

Skills For Crafts

Software Development Skills do not just happen. So, you need to take the bull by the horns and do it yourself. You need to make a plan because these skills rarely develop during your workdays. You also need to dedicate time to develop these skills. While in other craftsmanship, skills of good crafts are well-known. In software development, there is no consensus on this topic. In this talk, we are going to discuss the main skills every good developer should have and how to improve them. We will also share with you some tips and tricks but also some exercises we used to improve our software development skills.

Boris Gonnot , BISAM

Get your head in the Clouds!

If someone had said to you a few years back that they could build an app, 'push' to the cloud and even scale it in a matter of minutes with a few simple commands, you'd have most likely responded; 'You've got your head in the clouds'.

Times do change. This talk explains this phenomenon called Platform as a Service and how it can benefit you while demonstrating a real live deployment of an application with a blue green deployment and scale-up operation thrown in for fun.

The session will outline,

  • What is PaaS?
  • What options do I have?
  • How do I develop locally?
  • Dynamic Scaling of applications based on load
  • How do I build my application to be fault tolerant so I can dynamically scale?

Chris Cundill , Dilligent Software Ltd

Chris is an enthusiastic, experienced developer & designer of highly scalable and performant systems across a variety of sectors.Chris takes an active role in the local development community and has spoken and exhibited at various events in South Wales.

Building & Designing reactive, fault tolerant systems is a passion for Chris and getting your head in the clouds is the start of his journey to producing these kinds of systems in modern day cloud environments.

Giving back to the local community is very important for Chris who is a volunteer at a Primary School in South Wales as part of Code Club.

Architecture design for mobile applications, really?

How do you develop a scallable, fast and efficient cross platform mobile application? Creating a mobile application may sound trivial at first but, as many developers and teams have discovered, things can get complicated quickly. There are a lot of decisions to be made that have a direct impact on performance, efficiency, scalability and overall experience. Join Christos Matskas to learn how to choose the most appropriate mobile architecture and find out all the available technologies, strategies and patterns that will help you develop a successful mobile application that meets your business goals and quality objectives.

Christos Matskas , Microsoft (Azure)

Christos Matskas has been working as a software developer for the last 12 years. He is an entrepreneur, founder and CEO of SoftwareLounge, a software consultancy firm. His portfolio includes collaborations with some great companies such as MarkIT, Lockheed Martin and Barclays. Over the years he has worked on numerous exciting projects from mobile applications to data crunching back-end solutions. He writes about his adventures in software development on his blog https://cmatskas.com. Christos is an advocate of Open Source Software and a regular contributor to numerous projects. He's passionate about public speaking and he regularly speaks at conferences and user groups about .NET, the Cloud, mobile applications and software development in general (.NETFringe, DevWeek, MDevCon, SwanseaCon, Software Architect)

How and Why to Love Cucumber

Using Cucumber and BDD can change the experience of software developers and project teams dramatically for the better. Still, many are left with a poor impression of these tools and workflows because they aren’t using them in an optimal way. This talk gives specific, actionable strategies you can use to incorporate Cucumber and behavior-driven workflows into your projects to improve your results and spend more of your time doing work you love.

Dana Scheider , Tessitura

Dana Scheider is a developer who is passionate about behavior-driven development and about teaching others how to use BDD to enhance their experience as developers. Dana is an open source contributor and the founder of Tessitura, a SaaS company serving classical singers. A woman of many talents, Dana loves math and foreign languages and is also an operatic mezzo-soprano. She lives in Portland, Oregon (in the United States).

Let's Do Kano Analysis of SwanseaCon 2016 (Workshop)

Kano Analysis is a method which can be used for understanding which features your customers expect, are excited by, and want more of.

This workshop will introduce attendees to Kano Analysis, including how it can be used to categorise features for release planning. We'll discuss how to form questions to ask customers, how to interpret answers to those questions, and how to plan a release using those answers.

The workshop will encourage participation from attendees and use lots of examples to explore the topic. We'll use Kano to analyse SwanseaCon 2016 itself and explore what aspects of the conference would be classified as basic, linear and exciting features.

Dave Grant , Sorenson Media

Dave Grant is a product owner working for Sorenson Media in Cardiff, UK. He's worked in software development for the past 15 years, working as a developer, ScrumMaster, team leader and product manager.

Dave is one of the organisers of the South Wales Agile Group.

Scaling MySQL

Your new amazing code started off on a Vagrant image and now you want it to scale. The problem is that relational databases do not easily scale. Do you need to scale for reads, or writes, or both?? This session will cover the easy, low cost ways to move from your development box where all is on one image to splitting services, splitting reads/writes, basic sharding, highly available & fault tolerant server farms, to clusters with 99.999% up time. This talk will cover the costs (financial, time, opportunity cost, and sanity) as you scale with your data.

Dave Stokes , Oracle

Dave Stokes is a MySQL Community Manager for Oracle. Previously he was the MySQL Certification Manager for MySQL AB and SUN. He has worked for companies ranging alphabetically from the American Heart Association to Xerox and work ranging from Anti-submarine warfare to web developer.

Software Craftsmanship vs Lean Product

You want to get your product out to users, but you want to write clean code. Test your market fast but keep the product maintainable. Lean product development and software craftsmanship just can’t work together, right?

In the red corner, we have Elizabeth Ayer, Product Manager at Redgate. She loves Minimum Viable Products, cunning experiments, and The Lean Startup is her bible. Craftsmanship to her means wasting time polishing internals. Everyone loves sausages regardless of what goes on inside the factory.

Elizabeth Ayer , Redgate Software Ltd

Elizabeth Ayer is a product manager at Redgate Software, a company with 15 years' experience in Database Lifecycle Management. In her time there, she has investigated dozens of teams' software delivery processes. Above all, she is ridiculously passionate about shipping high-quality software fast.

Refactoring Legacy Code

Using a simple example, participants will look at how to deal with a mean mess of legacy code.

This presentation will contain live coding where we will solve the problem of making the code testable without breaking it. We will cover it with tests and change the design to be able to extend it, removing static calls, feature envy and singletons.

Franzi Sauerwein , Codurance

Franziska Sauerwein has been a software developer and consultant for several years. She is an active member of the European Software Craftsmanship community and loves to participate in their unconferences, such as SoCraTes. She organizes local code retreats, hackathons, coding dojos and tech talks. Her passions include Test Driven Development, XP techniques and high quality software development.

User-Story Point estimation: a new approach

Estimation is the weak spot of agile methodologies. Current methods for task estimation are subjective and inconsistent. This often results in failed sprints, which -in turn- lead to delivery failures, loss of credibility and team friction. We can't always estimate complexity and effort accurately, but there is a way to ensure our estimates are the best we can give, every single time, all the time.

The USP (User Story Point) estimation method is an algorithmic approach that takes into account technical and environmental factors affecting a User Story and uses a mathematical formula to produce a complexity point value.

During this talk I will explain the motivation and workings of the USP methodology and I'll demonstrate how to use it to provide consistent, objective and reliable estimates.

User-Story Point estimation: a new approach (Workshop)

This hands-on session will consist of a realistic scenario, where the audience will have the chance to apply the USP method to a project and thereby gain a better understanding of the USP methodology

Fred Heath , Independent

Fred is a software jack of all trades based in Cardiff, Wales. Over the last 20 years, he's worked at every stage of the software development life-cycle using a plethora of languages and platforms. After many years in the corporate world he is now a freelance developer and consultant who loves solving tricky problems, Ruby, FOSS, meta-programming, Behaviour-Driven Development and Agile processes. He also enjoys writing and speaking about software development and best practices.

Immutable Infrastructure for Mere Mortals

Server configuration drift has caused many bugs. Many more have been caused by differences between development and production. In this session, we will see how immutable infrastructure can help us to build clean, well-factored applications that we can reason about.

We will discuss:

  • What are the problems of treating servers like pets?
  • What is immutable infrastructure and how can it help?
  • How does it work?
  • How does an app need to be written to support II? (spoiler: 12 factor)

Gavin Davies , Radify

Gavin is a developer and automation engineer at Radify.io who believes that the best way to challenge yourself professionally is to freely share your knowledge with others. He is the author of the books 'Deal With It: Attitude for Coders' and 'Using build tools'. Gavin co-hosts the 'Never Out Of Beta' podcast. Gavin wrote his first lines of code in 1984 and can't see himself stopping any time soon.

Organisational Wide Agility

There is constant talk of scaling agile in the IT industry, but little talk about making organisations as a whole more agile. In this session you will hear some of the challenges of becoming agile across the entire organisation can bring, along with ways it can be achieved.

This isn’t about IT, this is about the business as a whole, which IT is a part of. Irrespective of what change the organisation wants to make, or how it can get better at running the business, thinking holistically is the only way you can achieve change.

Glenn Smith , Too Technical Ltd

Glenn is a techy at heart, but these days doesn’t get a chance to get his hands dirty in the code anymore. As a coach and trainer he helps organisation get better at product and service delivery and execution. He loves seeing people ‘get it’ and then going on to build great products, be that IT or non-IT alike.

With more than 16 years of experience, from the coal face of writing embedded software, to running a multi-disciplined team over two continents and having now supported many organisations, he has a wide range of skills and experiences. And in a past life he was a local politician, so can tell you lots of things about street lights and waste collection too!

Progressive Web Application: Instant Load and Offline Support

Over the past year, the Service Workers specification has been developed significantly. Why should we be excited? Service Workers offer a tone of functionality that means the mobile web can now rival native applications. This talk will explore how Service Workers can be used to create application that load instantly, support offline experience and push notifications on the web.

James Cryer , BBC

James is a Tech Lead, Principal Developer for BBC Weather & Travel delivering the next generation of web and mobile applications. James is the author of Pro Grunt.js, a book that takes developers on a journey on how to improve their developer workflow with Grunt.js. James has worked in the web industry for over 10 years working across a wide range of sectors with clients such as Investec Asset Management, Royal Navy, Unilever and Tesco. James has a passion for developer tooling and performance.

It doesn't always have to be Scrum

Scrum is becoming very popular; that’s good. Consciously or not, most people adopt Scrum by blindly following a so-called Scrum expert; that’s not so good.

As more organisations look to an Agile transition to become more efficient, I’m keen to make sure that they realise that there is more to Agile than just Scrum.

James Harvey , Agile Snap

A seasoned Agile veteran, James Harvey has been an Agile practitioner, coach and crusader for over a decade.

Recognised as an accredited training partner with the BCS, James is also certified Agile trainer focusing on the framework-agnostic BCS Agile syllabus.

KISS me quick; The battle against complexity

Brian Kernighan famously said that 'Controlling complexity [was] the essence of computer programming'. In comparison Dijkstra stated that 'Simplicity is a great virtue but... complexity sells better.'.

This talk posits that the main goal of technology, or of right minded people working in tech, is to deliver things of value in a just way. However, in an ever changing landscape, where business models and tools to deliver tech solutions are shifting at breakneck speed, what chance do developers and designers have in exercising just and tasteful solutions! This talk aims to look at what factors suggest inappropriate or over engineered design, considers how we may have got to this point, and what strategies might be employed to stop digging out of the hole, but starting filling it in.

Kingsley Davies , Inviqa

Kingsley has worked in senior tech roles for a number of organisations on a variety or projects, including Betfair, AKQA, Visa and the BBC. The stacks he's worked on tend to err towards functional programming (Scala), continuous delivery and evolving to be more agile. He's been involved in re-architecting technologies, processes and people and has noticed one commonality around a tendency towards the complex. As such, trying to understand what is complex in context has an is his main cause to advocate to help businesses.

Why so serious?

Don’t become a copy and paste machine, churning out the same old projects day after day. Stay on top of your game and harness any opportunity to get creative.

This talk looks at how doing something different can promote productivity, generate new ideas, and create great relationships.

Find out why we locked our teams in a house for 24 hours with nothing but their imaginations, and more importantly what happened!

Louise Howells , Zengenti

Louise joined Zengenti after a long stint in local government, and originally comes from a UX background. She leads a talented team, ranging from, developers and designers, to project managers and technical consultants. Delivering websites for the likes of LSE, the European University Institute, and the Royal Institute of British Architects.

Aside from that, Louise is a lover of teapot tea, watching the latest flicks at the cinema, and exploring different countries and cultures.

The 7 unmentioned challenges of Scrum

Organizations often start with Scrum after having heard about it, read about it, or after having read the Scrum Guide. While that is great, there are several unforeseen challenges they often face that prevent them from really benefiting from the advantages of Scrum. During this session we will discuss 'The 7 unmentioned challenges of Scrum' and we will work on uncovering possible solutions. There will be a strong focus on interaction during this session.

Maarten Kossen , Prowareness

Maarten is a Technical Agile consultant at Prowareness. In that role he helps teams and companies become responsive enterprises, often by starting with implementing Scrum and agile engineering practices. He also gives Scrum trainings and likes to speak at events on different topics. Maarten has a background in software development and has a passion for the internet and the hosting industry. In his spare time he likes to travel, spend time behind the PC and on the internet, and row on the ergometer. Maarten is a Starbucks Coffee addict (and collects their mugs as well) and likes to watch Top Gear (preferably while rowing).

Introducing Eager Design

What happens when the very frameworks, tools and patterns we cherish take the reins and forces us to focus on all the boilerplate scaffolding things, distracting us from really solving the real problems? Sometimes the outside-in approach can lead us to code that is more complex and coupled than it has to be.

Eager Design offers a fresh approach. Instead of being led by the delivery mechanisms, frameworks and patterns, we focus on the problems worth solving. Inspired by functional programming and Domain Driven Design, the principles of Eager Design helps us isolate and solve complex problems in a more focused and decouple manner.

Principles covered:

  • The problem with Outside-in development
  • Identifying opportunities for Eager Design
  • Jumping to the problem worth solving
  • Eagerly replacing primitives with values
  • Behaviour over state
  • Abstracting boundaries
  • Functional patterns applied in object oriented (immutability and persistency, identifying small units of behaviour, monoids, etc)

Marcello Duarte , Inviqa

Marcello Duarte is one of the creators of PhpSpec and heads the Training at Inviqa, a leading PHP consultancy business in Europe. He’s been awarded best UK Agile coach 2014 and has helped many teams in many organisations into Agile processes and development practices like Scrum, TDD, Refactoring, Collaborative Product Ownership and Software Quality.

Understanding abstractions. Or, how do regular expressions work?

All abstractions are leaky, and we tend to think of that as a bad thing. But sometimes it’s useful to be reminded of the implementation details. Knowing how something works under the covers often makes it a lot easier to use the abstraction. Take regular expressions - very powerful, yet very hard to use - arguably a write-only language! But once you know how the abstraction works, reading and writing a regular expression becomes a lot easier. In this talk, we’ll take a look at some popular, perhaps overlooked, abstractions, see how they work, and see how understanding the level below an abstraction makes you a better developer.

Matt Ellis , JetBrains

Matt Ellis is a developer advocate at JetBrains. He has spent 20 years shipping software and currently works with language tooling, having fun with abstract syntax trees and source code analysis. He owns and contributes to various open source projects, and believes in the open closed principle.

SonarQube to manage our technical debt and increase value

Code quality is very important, and it is also the best tool we have to ensure we are going to meet all the targets as a development eam. SonarQube with an existing pipeline is a great way of having a global overview of the general health state of our code, together with a detailed analysis of how we are faring - sometimes it might not be obvious, or we just can't see it!

Matteo Emili , Dell Software UK

Matteo Emili is a Microsoft MVP for Visual Studio ALM since 2010 and a Professional Scrum Master. Former Microsoft Student Partner (youngest ever in Italy and the first ever in being both MSP and MVP, in 2010 at the age of 19), he has a passion for Agile Methodologies, Processes and all the techie stuff around the code, which leads him to always searching for something new to share with the worldwide community around the Application Lifecycle Management field. He currently works for Dell Software UK as an Application Lifecycle Management advisor.

Stay credible, get growth

We make the software that we think people will want to use.

When working on our own projects, we need to find those people and convince them to give our stuff a try. As developers, we're not always comfortable with marketing or putting ourselves out there.

This session covers the basics of building awareness and adoption for your software, whether it's a free as in beer or paid-for. You'll learn the basics of building awareness, educating your users and building a community around your software.

In particular, we'll focus on building communities for tools aimed at developers (APIs, libraries, infrastructure).

We'll take a tour of the techniques of developer relations and growth hacking, while asking an important question: How do we get into this world while maintaining credibility?

Matthew Revell , Exoscale.ch

Director of Marketing and Community at Exoscale.ch, Matthew Revell has been been active in open source since the early 2000s. Before Couchbase he ran EMEA developer relations at Basho and before that worked with developer communities at Canonical.

In his spare time he runs DevRelCon, a conference for developer relations professionals, with editions in San Francisco and London.

The Heroes of programming - 10x developer myth

Mark Zuckeberg once said that there are developers 10, 100 times better that other ones. Of course Mark is an influential guy so his words has created this notion that there really are those Heroic developers somewhere that can save our projects and revolutionize our products. The only thing you need to do is find and attract them to join your crusade.

I was once a guy that also believed in it, working hard to become one of those Heroes. After 6 years trying to become one I have noticed that 10x work does exist but not in the way I imagined.

Join this talk to learn the truth behind 10x.

Michal Franc , JustGiving

Pragmatic team lead / dev that helps JustGiving build a social charity platform for 23+ mln users. Expert in .NET, interested in functional programming and JavaScript. VIM user, micro-service fan. Blog author www.mfranc.com, speaker. Found on twitter @francmichal and github michal-franc.

A Toolset for Creating a Potentially Releasable Product Increment

Working software is one of the four Agile values. However, Agile practitioners today are seen following anti-patterns like special sprints for integration, leaving regression testing to special QA focus groups etc. This talk will set the stage by defining the context leading to such decisions. and indicative symptoms. This talk will conclude with recommendations to address the anti-patterns described earlier. Narratives, real-world examples and lessons learned from actual experience will be provided for the audience as key takeaway.

Mohammad Nafees Sharif Butt , Viator (a TripAdvisor company)

Nafees is an Agile Coach and a software delivery agent with an eye for detail on the entire SDLC. He has coached & trained organizations and has helped them get better at delivering products that customers need. After coaching several teams at SMEs during last five years, Nafees is vetting some large scaled agile product development experiments within a corporate at the moment. His areas of interest include Agile software development (Scrum/Lean/XP/Kanban), Scaling Agile (LeSS, SAFe), deployment automation, continuous integration/delivery, test driven development (TDD), behavior driven development (BDD) and clean architecture.

Nafees is an avid learner and celebrates shared learning. He has spoken at international conferences in Australia, China and United Arab Emirates.

You can find a range of Nick’s opinions and speculations on his blog blog.ntcoding.com, covering topics from Continuous Delivery to the Business Model Canvas to polyglot programming.

Nick is also the co author of Patterns, Principles and Practices of Domain-Driven Design and the founder of London-based software consultancy Empathy Software. He is currently working as a Tech Lead and self-styled Scala evangelist on UK Government Projects.

Agile Remotely

The story of how adopting Agile practices helped me work remotely as part of a global team at IBM. Lessons learnt on our journey adopting Agile. How we use Agile methods to deliver across different time zones, working in a global marketplace. Including the many benefits of being in free to work independently of location.

Olly Brand , IBM

Technology consultant and IBMer: specialising in the design, build and run of Business Intelligence and Data Warehousing projects. Adopting Agile and SCRUM methodologies to run geographically diverse teams, with members all over Europe and India. Successfully delivering while living full time in Cornwall.

Known for Remote Working and Agile practices, including being featured in the Times, Guardian, and Financial Times.

From Scrum to Flow using Actionable Agile Metrics

This talk will detail the process of moving away from a ‘classic’ SCRUM based approach to planning (by using release planning, iteration planning, story points estimation using planning poker, etc) to an alternative method that uses a no estimate based approach.

The presentation will cover techniques that enable transitioning to this approach, such as: how to define work in progress, how to monitor throughput and ageing items, replenishment and right sizing as well as the use of Monte Carlo simulations for forecasting.

The techniques are based on Daniel Vacanti’s ‘Actionable Agile Metrics for Predictability’ and the presentation will contain practical aspects of how they have been applied at a major UK client.

Peter Pito , Deloitte Digital

Peter Pito is a Technical Lead at Deloitte Digital with 20 years experience designing and delivering software products.

He has worked as a software developer, consultant, managing director across a wide variety of domains and technologies.

His focus is on helping software teams deliver high quality software predictably.

Education for Engineers

How can we best design education programmes that prepare students to be effective software engineers in the modern world? What do they need to learn? How can we teach these things? Post-university, can we use the same principles to develop effective training and development programmes for professionals?

Many university degree programmes provide students with a solid grounding in the theoretical basis of computing, but it is difficult in a university environment to provide training in the types of software engineering techniques and practices, such as agile methods, that are commonly used in industrial development projects. There is typically a large gap between theoretical knowledge and practical experience.

In this session we will present how we have developed a programme that aims to bridge this gap, providing students with practical experience of relevant skills for industrial software engineering careers. We will give examples from courses at both Imperial College and Oxford. We are aiming to create courses that are practical and industrially relevant, but built on the fundamentals of computer science and rigorous engineering.

The first part of this session will be a talk giving some reflections on trying to improve the quality of a university course. Taking inspiration from modern ideas on lean and continuous delivery, we tried to adapt the course to provide higher quality learning, and give more value to the time the students spent studying. Universities are traditional organisations with long histories of doing things a certain way, and so whilst we had a lot of freedom over the content of the course, changing the format and the delivery methods was a lot harder.

We applied principles and tools from agile methods, aiming to increase the value of the time the students spent studying by providing feedback and learning in smaller batches, aided by automation. On a practical level, we will discuss the use of version control, automated testing, automated build and continuous integration for student exercises, and the effects that this has had. We will also discuss our attempts to teach the value of continuous delivery in larger student projects, the problems we have had with this, and ideas for future improvements.

Education for Engineers (Workshop)

How can we best design education programmes that prepare students to be effective software engineers in the modern world? What do they need to learn? How can we teach these things? Post-university, can we use the same principles to develop effective training and development programmes for professionals?

We will introduce the technique of Reverse Instructional Design, and change to a workshop phase. We will also discuss applying agile techniques and systems thinking to the design of the educational experience.

We will draw on the expertise and experience in the room to discuss (in small groups) the most important things for people to learn to work effectively in software development, and then try to design new possible course structures to address these using the techniques described. To finish we will compile the outputs from the groups.

Robert Chatley , Imperial College London

Robert is a visiting lecturer in Software Engineering at Imperial College London, and at the University of Oxford. Commercially Robert works as a consultant, coach and trainer with a focus on agile development.

Robert's previous experience includes working at Google, where he was an engineer on the team responsible for their Tv Ads product. He also acted as an agile coach and conducted training in agile development in Google's offices throughout the EMEA region. Before joining Google, Robert worked as a technical lead at Kizoom, one of the earliest companies in the UK employing XP at scale. He has chaired the XPDay conference, and acted as programme chair for the SPA conference. Robert holds an MEng degree in Information Systems Engineering and PhD in Software Engineering from Imperial College London.

Closing Keynote

After having coached agile projects for almost twenty years, author, craftsman and independent consultant Sander Hoogendoorn, looks back on what agile, Scrum, Kanban, XP and other agile approaches have brought us in real-life. In his well-known, high-speed style Sander will motivate why agile is dead, why you need to stay away from Scrum task-boards, how to stay away from estimates and deadlines, how to avoid red sprints, how to put your trust in metrics, how to draw owls, that projects are waste, and most of all that you are not Usain Bolt.

Sander Hoogendoorn , ditisagile.nl

Sander is an independent dad, mentor, trainer, software architect, programmer, speaker, and writer. He is a highly appreciated catalyst in the innovation of software development at his many international clients. Well known as the author of the best-selling book This Is Agile, Sander coaches organizations, projects and teams, has written books on UML and agile, and published over 250 articles in international magazines. He is an inspiring (keynote) speaker at many international conferences, and presents seminars and training courses on a variety of topics such as (beyond) agile, Scrum, Kanban, software estimation, software architecture, microservices, design patterns, modeling and UML, writing code, and testing.

Sandro is internationally renowned by his work on evolving and spreading Software Craftsmanship and is frequently invited to speak in many conferences around the world. His professional aspiration is to raise the bar of the software industry by helping developers become better at and care more about their craft.

Migration - from 'Jurassic Park' to MicroServices

How a migration to MicroServices could change the team, architecture and coding culture.

What you could do and how you could transform a 'Jurasic Park' into a lightweight environment.

In this talk we will explore the strategy, techniques, pattern and tools I used to transform a team and the architecture that was grown over 15yrs.

This will be a mix of pattern, tools and techniques that was able to migrate old systems, used inside ensurance and banks. We had to migrate fat systems that are handling in the average 500-300.000.000 docs.

Sven Ruppert , reply

Sven Ruppert has been coding Java since 1996. He is a Fellow for reply based in Munich.

In his free time he is regularly speaking at Conferences like JavaOne/Jfokus/Devoxx/JavaZone/and many more and contributes to IT periodicals, as well as tech portals.

How deep are your tests?

Manual testing is most often done end-to-end. Tests are performed through the user interface. When testing gets automated, this is where most organisations start. They start with automating the way they do things now. The new way is faster, but it isn’t fast enough. And not robust enough.

It is unnecessarily complicated to understand why an end-to-end test fails. There are usually many different possibilities when something doesn’t work.

The number of possible paths through a reasonably large application will very fast make it impossible to cover them all. Combinatorics is your enemy.

The solution is to minimise the tests that passes through many layers in your application. Minimising doesn’t mean removing the end-to-end tests. They are still needed. But much fewer than most organisations seem to think.

I will show you why the testing pyramid need to be very wide. You will understand why this is an absolute necessity if all possible paths through the application should be tested.

In other words, let me show you why your tests must be very shallow.

Thomas Sundberg , Independent

Thomas Sundberg is an independent consultant based in Stockholm, Sweden. He has a Masters degree in Computer Science from the Royal Institute of Technology, KTH, in Stockholm. Thomas has been working as a developer for more than 20 years. He has taught programming at The Royal Institute of Technology, KTH, one the leading technical universities in Sweden. Thomas has developed an obsession for technical excellence. This translates to Software Craftsmanship, Clean Code and Test Automation.

Thomas is a frequent speaker at different conferences and developer venues.

Thomas runs a blog where he writes about programming, Software craftsmanship and whatever problem he wants to share a solution about.

Seven ineffective coding habits many F# programmers don't have

At BuildStuff'14, Kevlin Henney presented an excellent talk titled 'seven ineffective coding habits of many programmers'. As an attendee that day and someone who has exhibited many of these habits over the years, I came to realize that using F# has cured me of many of these ineffective habits!

In this talk I'll share my thoughts on how the use of F# and functional programming techniques can help form and nurture good habits and give you the perfect practice you need to make perfect.

Yan Cui , Yubl

Yan is a Server Architect Developer at Yubl, and a regular speaker at user groups and conferences. He keeps an active blog at http://theburningmonk.com and is a co-author of 'F# Deep Dives'.

Meetings or Discipline, It's Your Choice

Meetings, both online and offline, are the most popular state-of-the-art instrument of resolving technical and management issues in software projects. I believe that this is what will be changed in the nearest future, revolutionary. Software teams will become more disciplined and organized. We won't use meetings as tools of management, design and architecture. In my presentation I will try to demonstrate how meetings can be replaced by a disciplined management process, empowered by modern tools or collaboration, diagramming and coding.

Yegor Bugayenko , Teamed.io

Yegor is a CTO and co-founder of Teamed.io, a software development company with a unique approach to management of distributed teams; a regular blogger at www.yegor256.com; a proud holder of PMP and OCMEA certifications; a hands-on Java developer and a lead architect of a few popular open source projects, including jcabi.com, takes.org, rultor.com and qulice.com. Yegor lives in Palo Alto, CA and Kyiv, Ukraine.
